class="mck-u-links-inline">Defense organizations are a major source of carbon emissions. How can they operate more sustainably while preserving mission-critical capabilities?</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_79c2a62 mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_79c2a62 mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_79c2a62">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_79c2a62"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Faerospace%20and%20defense%2Four%20insights%2Fdecarbonizing%20defense%20imperatives%20and%20opportunity%2Fdecarbonizing-defense-imperatives-and-opportunity.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_79c2a62" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="decarbonizing-defense-imperatives-and-opportunity" data-layer-report-name="decarbonizing-defense-imperatives-and-opportunity>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_79c2a62 mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_79c2a62 mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_79c2a62">Article (10 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Climate change</strong> is high on the global agenda. In the run-up to the 26th United Nations Climate Change (COP26) conference in Glasgow, governments and companies worldwide are announcing ambitious new decarbonization targets to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. While climate change as a national security matter is well understood, there is little consensus about how to align defense forces to address it.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>For defense forces, climate change brings wide-ranging risks, from undermining military assets to destabilizing societies to triggering conflict over resources. Defense forces, which typically account for at least 50 percent of governments’ carbon emissions, could help prevent these risks by taking dramatic action to decarbonize and reduce emissions. </p>
<p>Defense departments will encounter challenges when attempting to reduce the emissions for which they are directly responsible because of the primacy of having mission-critical capability (that is, the ability to achieve a desired effect in a specific operating environment), long equipment life cycles (which means fossil-fuel-powered equipment in use now, or coming into service shortly, will still be fielded in 2050), and an increased focus on niches with high emission intensity, such as space launch. In consequence, a complete elimination of all defense emissions is unlikely by 2050. A net-zero defense force will therefore need to find ways to compensate for these remaining emissions, such as by pursuing offsets in countries with high climate-change risk or by pushing for decarbonization beyond their own emissions.</p>
<p>For defense supply chains, the complexity of the full supplier landscape presents a challenge to quantifying and directly managing emissions. Defense forces have unique suppliers and unique products. This prevents the creation of an ecosystem to generate mutual benefits between defense forces and their suppliers, akin to the ones developing in the automotive sector that could help electric vehicles (EVs) displace vehicles with internal combustion engines. It may therefore be most effective to address supply-chain emissions by setting decarbonization requirements aligned
to national targets for all suppliers, as opposed to quantifying emissions directly and actively trying to reduce them.</p>
<p>Where possible, defense forces should benefit from off-the-shelf, low-carbon civilian technology, such as sustainable aviation fuel, fuel cells, and EVs. They should also build on these technologies in specific areas to develop more sustainable capabilities, such as supersonic flight with electric engines. With these tasks accomplished, defense forces could leverage their assets, including
their real estate, to decarbonize further in certain areas—for instance, by generating green power on bases or capturing carbon.</p>
<p>This article focuses on understanding the current emissions baseline and outlining how defense leaders could minimize emissions and deliver net-zero defense forces by 2050. It proposes a method for categorizing emissions to help defense leaders address trade-offs that are unique to defense organizations, such as the need to balance climate-change concerns against the inherent primacy of having mission-critical capabilities.</p>
<h2>Defense forces and carbon emissions</h2>
<p>Defense forces contribute a substantial amount to government CO₂ emissions. Estimates suggest that each year the US Department of Defense emits over 56 million metric tons of CO₂ equivalent (a metric ton of CO₂ equivalent measures emissions with the same global warming potential as one metric ton of CO₂). Of this amount, 60 percent is from vehicle, aircraft, ship and passenger-fleet emissions; 25 percent is purchased electricity; 10 percent is on-site fuel consumption at federal facilities; and 5 percent comes from other sources.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="23b7618a-f941-402d-8c50-a70c9e65ab06"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="23b7618a-f941-402d-8c50-a70c9e65ab06" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Comprehensive annual energy data and sustainability performance,” US Department of Energy, Federal Energy Management Program, 2020, ctsedwweb.ee.doe.gov; Hannah Ritchie and Max Roser, “CO₂ emissions,” Our World in Data, ourworldindata.org.</span></span></span></a></span> For perspective, consider that the entire country of Peru is responsible for emitting about 55 million metric tons of CO₂ annually.</p>
<p>Emissions from the US Department of Defense represent about 80 percent of emissions from the US federal government. In the United Kingdom, defense accounts for as much as 50 percent of government emissions<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f3985128-3a4f-472f-bc9c-6fbe414417ae"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f3985128-3a4f-472f-bc9c-6fbe414417ae" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Climate change and sustainability strategic approach</em>, UK Ministry of Defence, March 30, 2021, assets.publishing.service.gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span>; in Canada, the Department of National Defence is responsible for roughly half of the government’s fleet and facilities emissions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="60b6f98f-48e6-4f12-bc11-8a7dfa25395d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="60b6f98f-48e6-4f12-bc11-8a7dfa25395d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Inventory of federal greenhouse gas emissions fiscal year 2019 to 2020,” Government of Canada, last modified November 26, 2020, canada.ca.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_79c2a62"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_79c2a62"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/aerospace-and-defense/how-we-help-clients">Aerospace & Defense Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_79c2a62 mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_79c2a62 mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/aerospace-and-defense/how-we-help-clients" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_79c2a62"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_79c2a62">Learn more</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_79c2a62 mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>As governments elevate climate priorities and emphasize the need for net-zero emissions, they have begun to recognize the challenge posed by defense-related decarbonization. For many countries, decarbonizing their defense forces may be an essential step toward achieving government targets without relying on expensive offsets. </p>
<p>Given new impetus, sustainability has become an important agenda item for defense forces. In June 2021, NATO leaders confirmed their shared political commitment to reduce defense emissions, labeling climate change, “a defining challenge
of our times.”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a595bbf-8482-4807-a4cf-ce181bea8431"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a595bbf-8482-4807-a4cf-ce181bea8431" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“NATO climate change and security action plan,” NATO, June 14, 2021, stability and security.”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="32e04fb6-1247-4347-af1e-a879fdeef3c9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span a 33 percent reduction in heating and electricity CO₂ emissions between 2008 and 2018.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" of Defense offered details about how it will integrate sustainability into its mission and operations while noting that it had achieved a 23 percent reduction in emissions from 2008 to 2019 through, for example, a reduction in overall electricity use and greater use of renewable energy. More recently, US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin called climate change an “existential threat” and noted the importance of increasing the energy efficiency of platforms and installations, deploying clean distributed-energy generation and storage, and electrifying vehicle fleets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="175a6101-fa2e-400e-b17d-c4c1890134bb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="175a6101-fa2e-400e-b17d-c4c1890134bb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">David Vergun, “Defense secretary calls climate change an existential threat,” US Department of Defense, April 22, 2021, defense.gov.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Looking at levers similar to those under consideration in the United States, the UK Ministry of Defence is contributing to the government’s commitment to reach net-zero greenhouse-gas emissions by 2050. France has committed its armed forces to a three-pillar strategy designed to achieve climate neutrality by 2050, and Germany has also launched defense sustainability goals. While targets are a good starting point, none of these governments yet has a fully comprehensive public plan that involves hard choices, costs money, and requires substantial innovation.</p>
<h2>The need to reduce carbon levels without making unacceptable trade-offs</h2>
<p>To set priorities for decarbonization, defense forces can benefit from categorizing their emissions as those for which they are directly responsible (categorized as Scopes 1 and 2) and those resulting from the full supply chain, including both direct suppliers and subsuppliers (Scope 3). For these categories, defense-related emissions can be further assessed based on whether they are linked to mission-critical capabilities. Using this classification system, three types of defense-related emissions emerge: </p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Emissions that can be reduced, as in any other industry, given that they are not linked to mission-critical capabilities.</em> For Scopes 1 and 2, examples include emissions arising from head-office operations and the electricity and heating of estate or civilian vehicles (the “white fleet”). Examples of Scope 3 emissions include those for nonessential personnel transport (such as commuting or travel for meetings where video­conference could be used). Most defense forces will find a set of feasible opportunities for emissions reduction here.</li>
    <li><em>Emissions that are linked to mission-critical capabilities but can be addressed without any impact on the mission.</em> Examples of Scope 1 and 2 emissions include those from combat vehicles that could be electrified, those from naval vessels that could be made more fuel efficient, or those resulting from aircraft using fossil-based fuels on sorties where peak performance is not required. Scope 3 emissions in this category include those related to equipment maintenance or disposal. For this group, an assessment must conclude that there would be no detriment to capability, either through optimization, efficiency gains, or substitution, and there must be satisfaction with these findings across the defense community.</li>
    <li><em>Emissions that are related to mission-critical capabilities and where a decrease in emissions would affect those capabilities.</em> Examples of Scope 1 and 2 emissions include the use of fossil fuels during essential sorties where peak performance is required and those associated with space launches. Scope 3 emissions include those related to equipment transport from manufac­turing sites to operating sites. These emissions will be the hardest to decarbonize. Solutions available for such emissions include offsets or increased attention to innovation (for instance, generating renewable electricity on the defense estate).</li>
</ul>
<p>Defense forces have various options for reducing emissions, based on their source and their relation to mission-critical capabilities, as shown in the exhibit.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_79c2a62 mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/aerospace%20and%20defense/our%20insights/decarbonizing%20defense%20imperatives%20and%20opportunity/svg-decarbonizingdefense-v1-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Defense-force emissions can be categorized based on emission type and ease of reducing emissions." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/aerospace%20and%20defense/our%20insights/decarbonizing%20defense%20imperatives%20and%20opportunity/svg-decarbonizingdefense-v1-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Daunting as the challenge of decarbonization may be, there is much that defense forces can do without compromising their effectiveness. Indeed, some of the changes to enable decarbonization may also bear other operational or capability improvements, such as a reduced reliance on fossil supply chains or a greater ability to leverage local renewables.</p>
<h2>Understanding the emissions-reduction opportunity</h2>
<p>A reduction of up to about 60 percent of present-day Scope 1 and 2 emissions is achievable by focusing on the first two types of defense emissions: those that are not linked to mission-critical capabilities and those that are linked to mission-critical capabilities but can be addressed without any impact on the mission. This opportunity is based on an evaluation of potential emissions reductions from electricity and facilities, vehicles, aircraft, and vessels, which now account for about 95 percent of total emissions from the US Department of Defense. While it is unlikely that emissions will be eliminated entirely, any remaining emissions could be offset.</p>
<h3>Electricity and facilities</h3>
<p>Electricity and facilities now account for about 35 percent of the US Department of Defense’s Scope 1 and 2 emissions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="25413bc4-b17f-462d-a68b-4597a3c9e340"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="25413bc4-b17f-462d-a68b-4597a3c9e340" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Comprehensive annual energy data and sustainability performance,” 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/how-the-european-union-could-achieve-net-zero-emissions-at-net-zero-cost">McKinsey research</a>, which looked at emissions in Europe across industries, suggests that renewable power could satisfy more than 80 percent of primary energy demand by 2050. Example levers available to defense leaders include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Improving efficiency of the defense estate and bases. </em>This could be achieved with thermal insulation, systems that minimize water use, and improved waste-management systems.</li>
    <li><em>Transitioning to renewable heating. </em>This includes use of biofuels or heat pumps powered by renewable electricity.</li>
    <li><em>Using renewable power sources. </em>This includes solar systems that can take advantage of the large surfaces available (for example, rooftops or land on bases) to enable decarbonization. Green energy can also be sold back into the grid. A typical base could generate its annual electricity demand with 40 to 50 acres of solar panels, equivalent to the roof area of a midsize site.</li>
    <li><em>Installing <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/driving-co2-emissions-to-zero-and-beyond-with-carbon-capture-use-and-storage">carbon-capture technology</a> as it becomes more efficient and affordable. </em>Bases may be a logical site to install such technologies, particularly as defense forces build, operate, and occupy most of their estate, so the benefit of any upfront costs that lead to future cost reduction will be fully captured.</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Scaling sustainable aviation fuel today for clean skies tomorrow" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/scaling%20sustainable%20aviation%20fuel%20today%20for%20clean%20skies%20tomorrow/mck_tli_wef-image-standard-1536x1536.png?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_79c2a62"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_79c2a62"><div>Scaling sustainable aviation fuel today for clean skies tomorrow</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_79c2a62 mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_79c2a62 mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/scaling-sustainable-aviation-fuel-today-for-clean-skies-tomorrow" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_79c2a62"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_79c2a62">Read the report</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_79c2a62 mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h3>Vehicles, aircraft, and vessels</h3>
<p>Combat vehicles, aircraft, naval vessels, and the civilian fleet now account for about 60 percent of current US Department of Defense Scope 1 and 2 emissions, but this could be reduced by up to about 50 percent by 2050. Some initiatives to capture this opportunity include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Using drop-in biofuels for ships and some aircraft for selected missions</em> as some countries are already beginning to evaluate in trials. The Netherlands, Sweden, and the United States have all tested biofuels in selected air platforms, such as the F-16 and the JAS 39, while Italy has launched a project to promote widespread use of biofuels and nonfossil marine fuels. Trials by the Swedish Air Force have tested a fuel mix containing up to 50 percent sustainable aviation fuel, which has the potential to provide a life-cycle carbon reduction of up to 80 percent compared with traditional jet fuel.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f0cd2c2a-df67-4af2-858f-886a2f21257f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f0cd2c2a-df67-4af2-858f-886a2f21257f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Sweden continues to test fossil-free fuel using JAS 39 Gripen aircraft,” Airforce Technology, December 4, 2020, airforce-technology.com; “What is sustainable aviation fuel (SAF)?” Air BP, August 2020, bp.com.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Using more efficient engines, lightweight materials and more aero- or hydrodynamic designs.</em> Aircraft efficiency is expected to increase by 36 percent between 2020 and 2050, assuming minimal electrification.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7a4e936b-098e-4c3b-b51c-4e5d1d8dc715"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7a4e936b-098e-4c3b-b51c-4e5d1d8dc715" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Aircraft technology roadmap to 2050</em>, International Aircraft Transport Association, December 2019, iata.org.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Transitioning to alternative fuels for heavy-duty vehicles and naval vessels. </em>If this involves a nascent technology, such as hydrogen or e-methanol, for which the infrastructure does not currently exist, defense forces may need to begin investing to develop it, noting that this may also affect where private-sector funding flows. This could provide a 100 percent reduction in emissions if alternative fuels are generated sustainably.</li>
    <li><em>Using EVs for the “white fleet” of noncombat vehicles. </em>This could be implemented today and lead to a 100 percent reduction in these emissions (if combined with use of renewable power sources).</li>
    <li><em>Introducing electric unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs),</em> which, for missions where electric power is appropriate, could lead to a near-complete elimination of Scope 1 and 2 emissions. In this case, the switch to a low-carbon technology may even upgrade mission-critical capabilities, as it can increase stealth compared with fossil-powered alternatives. The financial cost is high, however. Any additional costs can be balanced against the capability and sustainability benefits.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Planning and behaviors</h3>
<p>Other opportunities to decarbonize involve changes in planning and behaviors. For instance, defense authorities could shift the live or synthetic balance
in training or improve planning by enhancing air-traffic flow or making logistics more efficient. They could also think about training staff on sustainability issues or promote greener modes of operations, such as by implementing policies that minimize travel whenever possible.</p>
<p><em><strong>Seeking to compensate for emissions in selected areas.</strong></em> It may become clear that some emissions cannot be reduced without affecting mission-critical capabilities. In such cases, defense authorities could strive to compensate for remaining emissions. They could also think about <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/driving-co2-emissions-to-zero-and-beyond-with-carbon-capture-use-and-storage">capturing CO₂ at the source</a> through carbon capture and storage or attempt to draw CO₂ out of the atmosphere through offsetting schemes. Funds could be found to support such initiatives, either directly from defense-force budgets or from other government sources. As defense authorities think about their options, it will be helpful to remember that their future offsetting costs will be higher if they decide not to pursue low-carbon options today, and that could affect their future mission-critical capabilities. </p>
<h2>Steps to a sustainable defense transition</h2>
<p>Making defense sustainable will involve a long journey. It can start with a few simple steps that involve planning strategically and taking actions that directly reduce environmental impact. In practice, these two activities will run in parallel, with early progress in implementing initiatives used to inform the ongoing sustainability strategy. Below we suggest eight steps (divided into four categories)
to consider.</p>
<h3>Understand the start and end points</h3>
<p><em><strong>Understanding emissions baseline and targets. </strong></em>The first step involves establishing the starting point and the destination so that governments can set and track sustainability targets. The work required to understand the emissions baseline can begin immediately, and governments in some countries, such as Canada, are already making progress in this area. Setting intermediate short-term steps—for instance, those for 2025 or 2035—also helps to build clarity on the pathway to net-zero emissions. All organizations seeking to reduce emissions can take this step by building an integrated pathway cost curve, which breaks the pathway into the individual measures required to achieve net-zero emissions. Each measure is defined in terms of the magnitude of emissions abatement it achieves against the weighted-average cost per ton of delivering that abatement.</p>
<p>For defense departments, the baseline of Scope 1 and 2 emissions can be quantified with high accuracy. By comparison, it will be nearly impossible to develop a full understanding of the Scope 3 baseline given the large number of suppliers and subsuppliers. As such, it may be necessary to impose decarbonization targets on suppliers, instead of directly quantifying their emissions and actively trying to reduce them.</p>
<h3>Enable change</h3>
<p><em><strong>Planning capabilities.</strong></em> Given the longevity of defense equipment, achieving decarbonization targets for 2050 will require action today. As a first step, defense authorities could review all equipment that will be fielded in the coming 30 years, including those already in service.</p>
<p>Most defense departments follow regular planning cycles, such as those outlined in the US Department of Defenses’ National Defense Strategy or the UK Ministry of Defence’s Integrated Review. As always, the planning cycles could help them identify the need for capability upgrades that will assist their operations in tougher future environments. These cycles could also be used as an opportunity to identify opportunities to decarbonize (always considering the impact on mission-critical capabilities, as discussed previously) and could even be used to make a full carbon budget through 2050 to understand the residual carbon emissions.</p>
<p>The findings from such planning may help defense authorities identify the best areas to focus R&D on and could lead to breakthroughs that will enhance capabilities, such as the development of hydrogen-fueled tanks. Finally, defense authorities could adjust the approvals process for proposals—for example, by stipulating that they include a low-carbon option, as well as the associated costs. This approach may help stimulate innovation and the development of new solutions.</p>
<p><em><strong>Considering how the organization can support change.</strong></em> Making defense forces more sustainable will inevitably bring change to complex organizations with established operating models. Given the size of this undertaking, defense authorities must establish the correct governance and provide incentives for the right behaviors to succeed.</p>
<p>Additionally, accountability for decarbonization is essential. This may be established by requiring the organizations responsible for emissions (typically the commands) to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions. By comparison, the acquisition agency may be best suited to address Scope 3 emissions. The separate organizations would then need to coordinate activities to ensure overall success.</p>
<p>Behavioral change is essential to operating more sustainably. At a minimum, staff members will need to understand the cultural change required to promote decarbonization. To attract a defense force’s top talent into decarbonization, sustainable actions must be incentivized and rewarded in the same way that actions to counter more traditional threats are.</p>
<p><strong><em>Creating a framework so more complex initiatives can be successful.</em></strong> Some initiatives required to hit overall sustainability targets may be difficult to implement. In such cases, they may require additional support from defense departments to ensure their success. This support may involve providing funding or incentives to conduct R&D
in a specific area, working with international partners to codevelop a solution (for example, similar to what was done at NATO for fuel standards), or seeking dedicated funding for a solution that would other­wise be unaffordable.</p>
<h3>Reduce emissions arising from their own organizations</h3>
<p><strong><em>Identifying and prioritizing initiatives. </em></strong>Typically, this step will involve highlighting emission-reducing initiatives along three dimensions. While availability and financial feasibility are important in any industry, the consideration of capability trade-offs is unique to defense and makes prioritizing initiatives more complex. The dimensions include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Availability of a solution. </em>Some problems may have available solutions because organizations within the private sector have already developed relevant decarbonization initiatives. If so, the defense sector can adopt similar strategies. Other problems may not have a viable solution available, either currently or in the
    near future.</li>
    <li><em>Financial feasibility.</em> Some sustainability initiatives will immediately produce positive financial results; others may cost money up front but could be financially beneficial over the long run. Yet more will have negative financial results but a positive impact on sustain­ability; this cost may be justified if the initiatives do not negatively affect capability.</li>
    <li><em>Capability trade-offs. </em>Some initiatives will let defense authorities decarbonize without reducing their mission-critical capabilities, and some may even increase capabilities. In other instances, however, the initiatives may inevitably put defense authorities at risk of reducing their mission-critical capabilities. Trade-offs will be important considerations for senior officers and policy makers, as compromises
    in performance are only acceptable in certain cases.</li>
</ul>
<p>If defense authorities consider scoring their initiatives against these three dimensions, it might help them to identify the appropriate levels of investment required for implementation. This scoring system could also help defense authorities
prioritize their initiatives.</p>
<h3>Consider how to reduce supply-chain emissions</h3>
<p>Decarbonizing the supply chain is essential to achieving overarching sustainability goals. Defense authorities have several levers available to achieve this goal, including providing incentives for low-carbon products, funding investment programs, or requiring suppliers to meet specific decarbon­ization goals or environmental-performance requirements to qualify for a defense contract. For instance, the UK Cabinet Office recently announced new measures that will require businesses
to commit to net-zero emissions by 2050.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d9b03874-9ba6-4334-8306-70a7ef2116a6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d9b03874-9ba6-4334-8306-70a7ef2116a6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">UK Cabinet Office. “Firms must commit to net-zero to win major government contracts,” June 7, 2021, gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> The businesses must also publish clear and credible carbon-reduction plans before they can bid for major government contracts, including those in defense. Additionally, defense authorities
could measure embedded carbon in defense products and incorporate sustainable procurement standards into the acquisition and decision-making processes. These steps would directly provide incentives for industries to reduce the carbon foot­print of their products and operations.</p>
<p>Defense authorities can also catalyze the creation of an ecosystem to encourage more sustainable production and manufacturing, for example, by chang­ing regulation and subsidizing sustainable change in their supply chain. In this way, organizations could generate mutual benefits in the long term. Departments could consider
using their position to promote sustainable R&D, such as that related to developing sustainable aviation fuels. They could also consider funding innovation programs that target improving the efficiency of next-generation equipment. These programs could be linked to future plans for upgrading or developing next-generation capabilities and may also be relevant for decarbonizing parts of the commercial sector.</p>
<hr>
<p>The challenge of making defense forces sustainable without compromising capability will be formidable. Defense personnel are trained to overcome great challenges with the tools available at hand, however, and they are in the privileged position
of being able to plan strategically. Now is the time for defense leaders to add sustainability to their agenda.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section How can they operate more sustainably while preserving mission-critical capabilities?"}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-07-01T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eClimate change\u003c/strong\u003e is high on the global agenda. In the run-up to the 26th United Nations Climate Change (COP26) conference in Glasgow, governments and companies worldwide are announcing ambitious new decarbonization targets to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. While climate change as a national security matter is well understood, there is little consensus about how to align defense forces to address it.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eFor defense forces, climate change brings wide-ranging risks, from undermining military assets to destabilizing societies to triggering conflict over resources. Defense forces, which typically account for at least 50 percent of governments\u0026rsquo; carbon emissions, could help prevent these risks by taking dramatic action to decarbonize and reduce emissions. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDefense departments will encounter challenges when attempting to reduce the emissions for which they are directly responsible because of the primacy of having mission-critical capability (that is, the ability to achieve a desired effect in a specific operating environment), long equipment life cycles (which means fossil-fuel-powered equipment in use now, or coming into service shortly, will still be fielded in 2050), and an increased focus on niches with high emission intensity, such as space launch. In consequence, a complete elimination of all defense emissions is unlikely by 2050. A net-zero defense force will therefore need to find ways to compensate for these remaining emissions, such as by pursuing offsets in countries with high climate-change risk or by pushing for decarbonization beyond their own emissions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor defense supply chains, the complexity of the full supplier landscape presents a challenge to quantifying and directly managing emissions. Defense forces have unique suppliers and unique products. This prevents the creation of an ecosystem to generate mutual benefits between defense forces and their suppliers, akin to the ones developing in the automotive sector that could help electric vehicles (EVs) displace vehicles with internal combustion engines. It may therefore be most effective to address supply-chain emissions by setting decarbonization requirements aligned\nto national targets for all suppliers, as opposed to quantifying emissions directly and actively trying to reduce them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhere possible, defense forces should benefit from off-the-shelf, low-carbon civilian technology, such as sustainable aviation fuel, fuel cells, and EVs. They should also build on these technologies in specific areas to develop more sustainable capabilities, such as supersonic flight with electric engines. With these tasks accomplished, defense forces could leverage their assets, including\ntheir real estate, to decarbonize further in certain areas\u0026mdash;for instance, by generating green power on bases or capturing carbon.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article focuses on understanding the current emissions baseline and outlining how defense leaders could minimize emissions and deliver net-zero defense forces by 2050. It proposes a method for categorizing emissions to help defense leaders address trade-offs that are unique to defense organizations, such as the need to balance climate-change concerns against the inherent primacy of having mission-critical capabilities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eDefense forces and carbon emissions\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDefense forces contribute a substantial amount to government CO₂ emissions. Estimates suggest that each year the US Department of Defense emits over 56 million metric tons of CO₂ equivalent (a metric ton of CO₂ equivalent measures emissions with the same global warming potential as one metric ton of CO₂). Of this amount, 60 percent is from vehicle, aircraft, ship and passenger-fleet emissions; 25 percent is purchased electricity; 10 percent is on-site fuel consumption at federal facilities; and 5 percent comes from other sources.[[Footnote 1]] For perspective, consider that the entire country of Peru is responsible for emitting about 55 million metric tons of CO₂ annually.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEmissions from the US Department of Defense represent about 80 percent of emissions from the US federal government. In the United Kingdom, defense accounts for as much as 50 percent of government emissions[[Footnote 2]]; in Canada, the Department of National Defence is responsible for roughly half of the government\u0026rsquo;s fleet and facilities emissions.[[Footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1Up dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eAs governments elevate climate priorities and emphasize the need for net-zero emissions, they have begun to recognize the challenge posed by defense-related decarbonization. For many countries, decarbonizing their defense forces may be an essential step toward achieving government targets without relying on expensive offsets. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGiven new impetus, sustainability has become an important agenda item for defense forces. In June 2021, NATO leaders confirmed their shared political commitment to reduce defense emissions, labeling climate change, \u0026ldquo;a defining challenge\nof our times.\u0026rdquo;[[Footnote 4]] Similarly, Germany\u0026rsquo;s Federal Defence Minister Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer has said the consequences of climate change \u0026ldquo;represent a key challenge for global stability and security.\u0026rdquo;[[Footnote 5]] Recognizing the threat of climate change, Germany\u0026rsquo;s defense forces achieved a 33 percent reduction in heating and electricity CO₂ emissions between 2008 and 2018.[[Footnote 6]] In its 2020 \u003cem\u003eSustainability Report \u0026amp; Implementation Plan\u003c/em\u003e, the US Department of Defense offered details about how it will integrate sustainability into its mission and operations while noting that it had achieved a 23 percent reduction in emissions from 2008 to 2019 through, for example, a reduction in overall electricity use and greater use of renewable energy. More recently, US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin called climate change an \u0026ldquo;existential threat\u0026rdquo; and noted the importance of increasing the energy efficiency of platforms and installations, deploying clean distributed-energy generation and storage, and electrifying vehicle fleets.[[Footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLooking at levers similar to those under consideration in the United States, the UK Ministry of Defence is contributing to the government\u0026rsquo;s commitment to reach net-zero greenhouse-gas emissions by 2050. France has committed its armed forces to a three-pillar strategy designed to achieve climate neutrality by 2050, and Germany has also launched defense sustainability goals. While targets are a good starting point, none of these governments yet has a fully comprehensive public plan that involves hard choices, costs money, and requires substantial innovation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe need to reduce carbon levels without making unacceptable trade-offs\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo set priorities for decarbonization, defense forces can benefit from categorizing their emissions as those for which they are directly responsible (categorized as Scopes 1 and 2) and those resulting from the full supply chain, including both direct suppliers and subsuppliers (Scope 3). For these categories, defense-related emissions can be further assessed based on whether they are linked to mission-critical capabilities. Using this classification system, three types of defense-related emissions emerge: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEmissions that can be reduced, as in any other industry, given that they are not linked to mission-critical capabilities.\u003c/em\u003e For Scopes 1 and 2, examples include emissions arising from head-office operations and the electricity and heating of estate or civilian vehicles (the \u0026ldquo;white fleet\u0026rdquo;). Examples of Scope 3 emissions include those for nonessential personnel transport (such as commuting or travel for meetings where video­conference could be used). Most defense forces will find a set of feasible opportunities for emissions reduction here.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEmissions that are linked to mission-critical capabilities but can be addressed without any impact on the mission.\u003c/em\u003e Examples of Scope 1 and 2 emissions include those from combat vehicles that could be electrified, those from naval vessels that could be made more fuel efficient, or those resulting from aircraft using fossil-based fuels on sorties where peak performance is not required. Scope 3 emissions in this category include those related to equipment maintenance or disposal. For this group, an assessment must conclude that there would be no detriment to capability, either through optimization, efficiency gains, or substitution, and there must be satisfaction with these findings across the defense community.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEmissions that are related to mission-critical capabilities and where a decrease in emissions would affect those capabilities.\u003c/em\u003e Examples of Scope 1 and 2 emissions include the use of fossil fuels during essential sorties where peak performance is required and those associated with space launches. Scope 3 emissions include those related to equipment transport from manufac­turing sites to operating sites. These emissions will be the hardest to decarbonize. Solutions available for such emissions include offsets or increased attention to innovation (for instance, generating renewable electricity on the defense estate).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDefense forces have various options for reducing emissions, based on their source and their relation to mission-critical capabilities, as shown in the exhibit.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eDaunting as the challenge of decarbonization may be, there is much that defense forces can do without compromising their effectiveness. Indeed, some of the changes to enable decarbonization may also bear other operational or capability improvements, such as a reduced reliance on fossil supply chains or a greater ability to leverage local renewables.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eUnderstanding the emissions-reduction opportunity\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA reduction of up to about 60 percent of present-day Scope 1 and 2 emissions is achievable by focusing on the first two types of defense emissions: those that are not linked to mission-critical capabilities and those that are linked to mission-critical capabilities but can be addressed without any impact on the mission. This opportunity is based on an evaluation of potential emissions reductions from electricity and facilities, vehicles, aircraft, and vessels, which now account for about 95 percent of total emissions from the US Department of Defense. While it is unlikely that emissions will be eliminated entirely, any remaining emissions could be offset.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eElectricity and facilities\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eElectricity and facilities now account for about 35 percent of the US Department of Defense\u0026rsquo;s Scope 1 and 2 emissions.[[Footnote 8]] \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/how-the-european-union-could-achieve-net-zero-emissions-at-net-zero-cost\"\u003eMcKinsey research\u003c/a\u003e, which looked at emissions in Europe across industries, suggests that renewable power could satisfy more than 80 percent of primary energy demand by 2050. Example levers available to defense leaders include the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eImproving efficiency of the defense estate and bases. \u003c/em\u003eThis could be achieved with thermal insulation, systems that minimize water use, and improved waste-management systems.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTransitioning to renewable heating. \u003c/em\u003eThis includes use of biofuels or heat pumps powered by renewable electricity.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUsing renewable power sources. \u003c/em\u003eThis includes solar systems that can take advantage of the large surfaces available (for example, rooftops or land on bases) to enable decarbonization. Green energy can also be sold back into the grid. A typical base could generate its annual electricity demand with 40 to 50 acres of solar panels, equivalent to the roof area of a midsize site.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInstalling \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/driving-co2-emissions-to-zero-and-beyond-with-carbon-capture-use-and-storage\"\u003ecarbon-capture technology\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;as it becomes more efficient and affordable. \u003c/em\u003eBases may be a logical site to install such technologies, particularly as defense forces build, operate, and occupy most of their estate, so the benefit of any upfront costs that lead to future cost reduction will be fully captured.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[Disruptor1Up dis2]]\n\u003ch3\u003eVehicles, aircraft, and vessels\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCombat vehicles, aircraft, naval vessels, and the civilian fleet now account for about 60 percent of current US Department of Defense Scope 1 and 2 emissions, but this could be reduced by up to about 50 percent by 2050. Some initiatives to capture this opportunity include the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUsing drop-in biofuels for ships and some aircraft for selected missions\u003c/em\u003e as some countries are already beginning to evaluate in trials. The Netherlands, Sweden, and the United States have all tested biofuels in selected air platforms, such as the F-16 and the JAS 39, while Italy has launched a project to promote widespread use of biofuels and nonfossil marine fuels. Trials by the Swedish Air Force have tested a fuel mix containing up to 50 percent sustainable aviation fuel, which has the potential to provide a life-cycle carbon reduction of up to 80 percent compared with traditional jet fuel.[[Footnote 9]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUsing more efficient engines, lightweight materials and more aero- or hydrodynamic designs.\u003c/em\u003e Aircraft efficiency is expected to increase by 36 percent between 2020 and 2050, assuming minimal electrification.[[Footnote 10]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTransitioning to alternative fuels for heavy-duty vehicles and naval vessels. \u003c/em\u003eIf this involves a nascent technology, such as hydrogen or e-methanol, for which the infrastructure does not currently exist, defense forces may need to begin investing to develop it, noting that this may also affect where private-sector funding flows. This could provide a 100 percent reduction in emissions if alternative fuels are generated sustainably.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUsing EVs for the \u0026ldquo;white fleet\u0026rdquo; of noncombat vehicles. \u003c/em\u003eThis could be implemented today and lead to a 100 percent reduction in these emissions (if combined with use of renewable power sources).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIntroducing electric unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs),\u003c/em\u003e which, for missions where electric power is appropriate, could lead to a near-complete elimination of Scope 1 and 2 emissions. In this case, the switch to a low-carbon technology may even upgrade mission-critical capabilities, as it can increase stealth compared with fossil-powered alternatives. The financial cost is high, however. Any additional costs can be balanced against the capability and sustainability benefits.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePlanning and behaviors\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther opportunities to decarbonize involve changes in planning and behaviors. For instance, defense authorities could shift the live or synthetic balance\nin training or improve planning by enhancing air-traffic flow or making logistics more efficient. They could also think about training staff on sustainability issues or promote greener modes of operations, such as by implementing policies that minimize travel whenever possible.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSeeking to compensate for emissions in selected areas.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e It may become clear that some emissions cannot be reduced without affecting mission-critical capabilities. In such cases, defense authorities could strive to compensate for remaining emissions. They could also think about \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/driving-co2-emissions-to-zero-and-beyond-with-carbon-capture-use-and-storage\"\u003ecapturing CO₂ at the source\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;through carbon capture and storage or attempt to draw CO₂ out of the atmosphere through offsetting schemes. Funds could be found to support such initiatives, either directly from defense-force budgets or from other government sources. As defense authorities think about their options, it will be helpful to remember that their future offsetting costs will be higher if they decide not to pursue low-carbon options today, and that could affect their future mission-critical capabilities. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSteps to a sustainable defense transition\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMaking defense sustainable will involve a long journey. It can start with a few simple steps that involve planning strategically and taking actions that directly reduce environmental impact. In practice, these two activities will run in parallel, with early progress in implementing initiatives used to inform the ongoing sustainability strategy. Below we suggest eight steps (divided into four categories)\nto consider.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eUnderstand the start and end points\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUnderstanding emissions baseline and targets. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003eThe first step involves establishing the starting point and the destination so that governments can set and track sustainability targets. The work required to understand the emissions baseline can begin immediately, and governments in some countries, such as Canada, are already making progress in this area. Setting intermediate short-term steps\u0026mdash;for instance, those for 2025 or 2035\u0026mdash;also helps to build clarity on the pathway to net-zero emissions. All organizations seeking to reduce emissions can take this step by building an integrated pathway cost curve, which breaks the pathway into the individual measures required to achieve net-zero emissions. Each measure is defined in terms of the magnitude of emissions abatement it achieves against the weighted-average cost per ton of delivering that abatement.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor defense departments, the baseline of Scope 1 and 2 emissions can be quantified with high accuracy. By comparison, it will be nearly impossible to develop a full understanding of the Scope 3 baseline given the large number of suppliers and subsuppliers. As such, it may be necessary to impose decarbonization targets on suppliers, instead of directly quantifying their emissions and actively trying to reduce them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEnable change\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePlanning capabilities.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e Given the longevity of defense equipment, achieving decarbonization targets for 2050 will require action today. As a first step, defense authorities could review all equipment that will be fielded in the coming 30 years, including those already in service.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost defense departments follow regular planning cycles, such as those outlined in the US Department of Defenses\u0026rsquo; National Defense Strategy or the UK Ministry of Defence\u0026rsquo;s Integrated Review. As always, the planning cycles could help them identify the need for capability upgrades that will assist their operations in tougher future environments. These cycles could also be used as an opportunity to identify opportunities to decarbonize (always considering the impact on mission-critical capabilities, as discussed previously) and could even be used to make a full carbon budget through 2050 to understand the residual carbon emissions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe findings from such planning may help defense authorities identify the best areas to focus R\u0026amp;D on and could lead to breakthroughs that will enhance capabilities, such as the development of hydrogen-fueled tanks. Finally, defense authorities could adjust the approvals process for proposals\u0026mdash;for example, by stipulating that they include a low-carbon option, as well as the associated costs. This approach may help stimulate innovation and the development of new solutions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConsidering how the organization can support change.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e Making defense forces more sustainable will inevitably bring change to complex organizations with established operating models. Given the size of this undertaking, defense authorities must establish the correct governance and provide incentives for the right behaviors to succeed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdditionally, accountability for decarbonization is essential. This may be established by requiring the organizations responsible for emissions (typically the commands) to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions. By comparison, the acquisition agency may be best suited to address Scope 3 emissions. The separate organizations would then need to coordinate activities to ensure overall success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBehavioral change is essential to operating more sustainably. At a minimum, staff members will need to understand the cultural change required to promote decarbonization. To attract a defense force\u0026rsquo;s top talent into decarbonization, sustainable actions must be incentivized and rewarded in the same way that actions to counter more traditional threats are.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eCreating a framework so more complex initiatives can be successful.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Some initiatives required to hit overall sustainability targets may be difficult to implement. In such cases, they may require additional support from defense departments to ensure their success. This support may involve providing funding or incentives to conduct R\u0026amp;D\nin a specific area, working with international partners to codevelop a solution (for example, similar to what was done at NATO for fuel standards), or seeking dedicated funding for a solution that would other­wise be unaffordable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eReduce emissions arising from their own organizations\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eIdentifying and prioritizing initiatives. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eTypically, this step will involve highlighting emission-reducing initiatives along three dimensions. While availability and financial feasibility are important in any industry, the consideration of capability trade-offs is unique to defense and makes prioritizing initiatives more complex. The dimensions include the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAvailability of a solution. \u003c/em\u003eSome problems may have available solutions because organizations within the private sector have already developed relevant decarbonization initiatives. If so, the defense sector can adopt similar strategies. Other problems may not have a viable solution available, either currently or in the\n    near future.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFinancial feasibility.\u003c/em\u003e Some sustainability initiatives will immediately produce positive financial results; others may cost money up front but could be financially beneficial over the long run. Yet more will have negative financial results but a positive impact on sustain­ability; this cost may be justified if the initiatives do not negatively affect capability.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCapability trade-offs. \u003c/em\u003eSome initiatives will let defense authorities decarbonize without reducing their mission-critical capabilities, and some may even increase capabilities. In other instances, however, the initiatives may inevitably put defense authorities at risk of reducing their mission-critical capabilities. Trade-offs will be important considerations for senior officers and policy makers, as compromises\n    in performance are only acceptable in certain cases.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf defense authorities consider scoring their initiatives against these three dimensions, it might help them to identify the appropriate levels of investment required for implementation. This scoring system could also help defense authorities\nprioritize their initiatives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eConsider how to reduce supply-chain emissions\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDecarbonizing the supply chain is essential to achieving overarching sustainability goals. Defense authorities have several levers available to achieve this goal, including providing incentives for low-carbon products, funding investment programs, or requiring suppliers to meet specific decarbon­ization goals or environmental-performance requirements to qualify for a defense contract. For instance, the UK Cabinet Office recently announced new measures that will require businesses\nto commit to net-zero emissions by 2050.[[Footnote 11]] The businesses must also publish clear and credible carbon-reduction plans before they can bid for major government contracts, including those in defense. Additionally, defense authorities\ncould measure embedded carbon in defense products and incorporate sustainable procurement standards into the acquisition and decision-making processes. These steps would directly provide incentives for industries to reduce the carbon foot­print of their products and operations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDefense authorities can also catalyze the creation of an ecosystem to encourage more sustainable production and manufacturing, for example, by chang­ing regulation and subsidizing sustainable change in their supply chain. In this way, organizations could generate mutual benefits in the long term. Departments could consider\nusing their position to promote sustainable R\u0026amp;D, such as that related to developing sustainable aviation fuels. They could also consider funding innovation programs that target improving the efficiency of next-generation equipment. These programs could be linked to future plans for upgrading or developing next-generation capabilities and may also be relevant for decarbonizing parts of the commercial sector.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe challenge of making defense forces sustainable without compromising capability will be formidable. Defense personnel are trained to overcome great challenges with the tools available at hand, however, and they are in the privileged position\nof being able to plan strategically. Now is the time for defense leaders to add sustainability to their agenda.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE
